>
[Nodachi](/Weapons.aspx?ID=298)
</title>

<traits>
<trait label="Brace" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=471" />
<trait label="Deadly d12" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=174" />
<trait label="Reach" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=192" />
</traits>

<column gap="tiny">

<row gap="tiny">**Source** [Treasure Vault](/Sources.aspx?ID=191) pg. 27 <sup>1.1</sup></row>

<row gap="medium">
**Price** 6 gp

**Damage** 1d8 S

**Bulk** 2
</row>

<row gap="medium">
**Hands** 2

</row>

<row gap="medium">
**Category** Advanced

**Group** [Sword](/WeaponGroups.aspx?ID=15)
</row>

</column>

---

Also known as a zhanmadao, the exceptionally long blade of the nodachi is designed to neutralize enemy mounts and counter the advantages of cavalry units. Its shape and size make it somewhat impractical for close combat but highly effective against charging opponents.

<title level="2">Critical Specialization Effects</title>

<row gap="tiny">**Source** [Core Rulebook](/Sources.aspx?ID=1) pg. 283 <sup>4.0</sup></row>

Certain feats, class features, weapon runes, and other effects can grant you additional benefits when you make a Strike with certain weapons and get a critical success. This is called a critical specialization effect. The exact effect depends on which weapon group your weapon belongs to, as listed below. You can always decide not to add the critical specialization effect of your weapon.

[Click here for the full rules on Critical Specialization Effects](/Rules.aspx?ID=235).
